children.name: understand
children.definition: to understand how sb feels, and feel sympathy for them, especially when they are upset or have problems: hiểu
examples: I’m sure your teacher will understand.
My parents just don’t understand me.
Just tell him how you feel – I’m sure he’ll understand.
understand how/what/why etc
I understand how you feel, but I still think you should apologize to her.
I understand how you feel, but I think you’re overreacting.
(can) understand somebody doing something
I can understand her wanting to live alone and be independent.

children.name: see
children.definition: especially spoken to understand how sb feels and why they feel that way, especially because the reasons are very clear: hiểu, thấy được
examples: see why/how/what
You can see why Clare was so annoyed, can’t you?
see that
I can see that you’d find that upsetting.

children.name: appreciate
children.definition: formalto understand clearly how someone feels or whatproblemsthey have:hiểu, thông cảm
examples: Congress did not appreciate the amount of anger that people felt about this issue.
Parents have to find ways to show their children that they appreciate their feelings and reactions.
appreciate (that)
I appreciate that it’s not easy for you, but you must try to get here on time.

children.name: know how sb feels
children.definition: know how somebody feels to understand how sb feels, because you have had the same feelings or experiences yourself:hiểu được cảm giác của ai
examples: ▪ I know how you feel. I couldn’t watch either - it was too upsetting.
know how it feels (to do sth)
▪ Believe me, I know how it feels to lose.

children.name: put yourself in sb’s place
children.definition: put yourself in somebody’s place say this when you want someone to imagine they are in the same situation as another person, so that they can understand how the other person feels: đặt mình vào vị trí của ai
examples: ▪ Well, put yourself in her place. Would you like it if someone did that to you?

children.name: understandable
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈstændəbəl/ feelingsorattitudesthat are understandable, especially feelings of anger, annoyance, or fear, do not surprise you because you can see that there are good reasons for them: có thể hiểu được
examples: ▪ That teachers are annoyed about having so much extra paperwork is understandable.
▪ There is understandable anger among the victims’ families.
it is understandable that
▪ It’s understandable that she doesn’t want to see Bill again.
understandably[adverb]
▪ Understandably, she just wants to leave as soon as possible.
▪ They were, quite understandably, annoyed by the delay.

children.name: relating to sb who is so unlucky, so unhappy etc that you feel sorry for them
poor
children.definition: /pʊəʳ/  especially spoken use this to talk to or about someone that you feel sorry for:tội nghiệp
examples: ▪ The poor girl gets blamed for everything that goes wrong.
▪ Poor baby. Come here and let me give you a cuddle.
poor oldinformal:tội nghiệp
▪ I hear poor old Steve broke his ankle.

children.name: pitiful
children.definition: /ˈpɪtɪfəl/  a pitiful person looks or sounds very sad and unlucky and you feel very sorry for them:đáng thương
examples: ▪ John looked pitiful, his whole body weak with exhaustion.
▪ the pitiful cries of an injured puppy
▪ The horses were in a pitiful condition, thin and covered with sores.
pitifully[adverb]một cách đáng thương
▪ The woman sobbed pitifully, begging to be left alone.

children.name: pathetic
children.definition: /pəˈθetɪk/  someone who is pathetic is someone that you feel sorry for even though you often also have no respect for them:thảm hại, cảm động
examples: ▪ There is something pathetic about a 40-year-old man who still has his mother do his laundry.
▪ Yang looked at me with a pathetic expression on his face.
▪ We found a small dog sitting outside the back door, looking pathetic.
pathetically[adverb]một cách thảm hại
▪ ‘No one ever listens to me,’ she said pathetically.
▪ Suddenly, he looks pathetically young and scared.

children.name: wretched
children.definition: /ˈretʃɪd, ˈretʃəd/  someone who is wretched is very unhappy or unlucky, so that you feel very sorry for them - used especially in literature:không ai, không may mắn
examples: ▪ With a violent drunkard for a husband, he thought, that wretched woman must lead a life of terror.
▪ Billy lay on the bed, wretched and close to tears.

children.name: empathy
children.definition: the ability to understand other people’s feelings and problems →sympathy: sự thấu cảm, khả năng hiểu thấu lòng người
examples: empathy with/for
She had great empathy with people.

children.name: sb who is kind and shows sympathy
sympathetic
children.definition: /ˌsɪmpəˈθetɪk◂/  kind to people who are in an unpleasant situation, and ready to comfort them or share their problems:thông cảm
examples: ▪ My friends were all extremely sympathetic when they heard I’d lost my job.
▪ Noticing my embarrassment, the teacher gave me a sympathetic smile.
sympathetic to/towards: thông cảm cho ai/đối với
▪ Try being a bit more sympathetic towards her -- you might get better results.
sympathetically[adjective]một cách đầy cảm thông
▪ She listened sympathetically to all our complaints.
▪ Kramer nodded sympathetically.

children.name: understanding
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈstændɪŋ/  sympathetic and patient, even when someone behaves badly, because you understand their problems and feelings:thông hiểu, thông cảm
examples: ▪ He’s funny, energetic, understanding, and a great teacher.
▪ Irene often has to take time off work. Fortunately she has a very understanding boss.
▪ My parents were wonderfully understanding throughout my divorce.

children.name: compassionate
children.definition: /kəmˈpæʃənɪt, kəmˈpæʃənət/  someone who is compassionate feels a lot of pity for people who are suffering and wants to help them:thương xót
examples: ▪ The church has inspired countless compassionate men and women to help the needy in times of famine, war, and plague.
compassionate to/towards: lòng thương sót cho/đối với ai/cái gì
▪ Our city has earned a reputation as a place where government is compassionate toward the poor and disadvantaged.
compassionately[adverb]một cách đầy thương sót
▪ Political refugees need our protection and we urge the government to view their plight more compassionately.

children.name: caring
children.definition: /ˈkeərɪŋ/  loving and sympathetic, especially so that you want to help people when they are in trouble:chu đáo
examples: ▪ Just because a family has money does not guarantee that the children have responsible and caring parents.
▪ It is possible for men to be tough and, at the same time, caring and sensitive.

children.name: a sympathetic ear
children.definition: /a shoulder to cry on/ə ˌsɪmpəθetɪk ˈɪəʳ, ə ˌʃəʊldəʳ tə ˈkraɪ ɒn/  someone who will listen sympathetically when you tell them about your troubles:chỗ dựa, nơi dựa dẫm
examples: ▪ Remember your mother’s always here if you need a shoulder to cry on.
▪ Watt found a sympathetic ear when he described his family’s situation to Captain Schiller.

children.name: sensitive
children.definition: able to understand other people’s feelings and problemsOPP insensitive: nhạy bén
examples: a sensitive and intelligent young man
In the movie, he plays a concerned and sensitive father trying to bring up two teenage children on his own.
sensitive to
It’s made me much more sensitive to the needs of the disabled.
Representatives of the company claim their plan will be sensitive to local needs.

children.name: to understand sb because you are like them
relate to
children.definition: /rɪˈleɪt tuː/  to be able to understand and be sympathetic to someone, because you have the same problems, situation etc as them:
examples: ▪ Group work helps children learn to share things and relate to each other.
▪ He seems to have difficulty relating to others and expressing his feelings.
▪ She’s a great teacher because she really relates to the kids.

children.name: identify with
children.definition: /aɪˈdentɪfaɪ wɪð, aɪˈdentəfaɪ wɪð/  to like someone because you feel that they are similar to you:
examples: ▪ Which of the characters do you most identify with?
▪ Winters believes she has been successful because people identify with her and trust her.
▪ We can all identify with these people in their desire for freedom and independence.

children.name: kind to people who have problems and difficulties
sympathetic
children.definition: /ˌsɪmpəˈθetɪk◂/  kind to people who are in an unpleasant situation, and ready to comfort them or share their problems:
examples: cảm thông , đồng cảm
▪ My friends were all extremely sympathetic when they heard I’d lost my job.
▪ Noticing my embarrassment, the teacher gave me a sympathetic smile.
sympathetic to/towards
thông cảm với/hướng tới
▪ Try being a bit more sympathetic towards her -- you might get better results.
sympathetically[adjective]
thông cảm
▪ She listened sympathetically to all our complaints.
▪ Kramer nodded sympathetically.

children.name: good
children.definition: /gʊd/  if you are good to someone, especially someone who is old, young, sick etc, you are kind to them and give them what they need:
examples: tốt bụng
good to
tốt bụng để
▪ My stepfather’s always been very good to me and treated me like one of his own children.
it is good of somebody (to do something)
Điều đó làm ai đó tốt lên
▪ It’s good of you to see me at such short notice.

children.name: understanding
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈstændɪŋ/  an understanding person is kind and patient when someone has a problem, and does not get angry with them or criticize them:
examples: biết cảm thông, biết đồng cảm
▪ I’m sorry I’ve been so bad-tempered lately. Anyway, thank you for being so understanding.
▪ Irene often has to take time off work. Fortunately she has a very understanding boss.

children.name: compassionate
children.definition: /kəmˈpæʃənɪt, kəmˈpæʃənət/  someone who is compassionate wants to help people who are suffering or having problems:
examples: thương hại, thương xót, động lòng thương, động lòng trắc ẩn
▪ Alice was a compassionate woman who wanted to save children from violence and poverty.
▪ We must try to create a more caring, more compassionate society.
compassionately[adverb]
từ bi
▪ Political refugees need our protection and we urge the government to view their plight more compassionately.

children.name: caring
children.definition: /ˈkeərɪŋ/  loving and sympathetic, especially so that you want to help people close to you when they are in trouble:
examples: chu đáo
▪ Sharon was lucky to have such caring parents at a time when she needed help.
▪ It is possible for men to be tough and, at the same time, caring and sensitive.
caringadjective chu đáo
describes someone who is kind and gives emotional support to others
_I've always thought of Jo as a very caring person.

children.name: kind-hearted
children.definition: /ˌkaɪnd ˈhɑːʳtd◂/  someone who is kind-hearted has a kind and sympathetic character:
examples: tốt bụng, có lòng tốt
▪ Being a kind-hearted woman, she felt sorry for the poor child.
▪ I wouldn’t have helped him at all, but then I’m not as kind-hearted as you.
kind-heartedadjective tốt bụng;có lòng tốt
A kind-hearted person is one who likes other people a lot and always wants to help them.

children.name: a shoulder to cry on
children.definition: /ə ˌʃəʊldəʳ tə ˈkraɪ ɒn/  informal someone who will listen sympathetically when you tell them about your problems:
examples: một bờ vai để dựa vào
▪ Remember, I’m always here if you need a shoulder to cry on.

children.name: to not feel sorry for sb in a bad situation
have/feel no sympathy for
children.definition: /hæv, fiːl ˌnəʊ ˈsɪmpəθi fɔːʳ/  to feel that someone’s problems are their own fault:không có sự cảm thương cho ai
examples: ▪ I have no sympathy for him - he hasn’t even tried to look for a job.
▪ I’m afraid I don’t have much sympathy for people who spend more than they can afford and then find themselves in debt.
have/feel little sympathy for somebody: hầu như không có sự thương cảm cho ai
▪ The fact is that most Americans feel little sympathy for AIDS sufferers.

children.name: my heart bleeds (for sb)
children.definition: my heart bleeds (for somebody)/maɪ ˌhɑːʳt ˈbliːdz (fəʳ somebody )/ spoken use this humorously when you do not feel any sympathy at all for someone:cảm thấy đau xót cho ai
examples: ▪ ‘He says he can’t come out tonight because he has to look after the kids.’ ‘My heart bleeds! That must be the first time he’s stayed in with them since they were born!’

children.name: to try to make sb feel sorry for you
hard-luck story/sob story
children.definition: /ˌhɑːʳd ˈlʌk ˌstɔːri, ˈsɒb ˌstɔːriǁˈsɑːb-/  a story or explanation, especially one that is untrue, told by someone in order to make other people feel sorry for them:lời giải thích bịa đặt
examples: ▪ A beggar approached me with some hard-luck story about an accident.give somebody a hard-luck/sob story
▪ The defendant gave us some sob story about a sick child.

children.name: play on sb’s sympathy
children.definition: play on somebody’s sympathyalso play for sympathy /ˌpleɪ ɒn somebodyˈs ˈsɪmpəθi, ˌpleɪ fəʳ ˈsɪmpəθi/  to unfairly try to make someone feel sorry for you, in order to gain an advantage for yourself:lợi dụng lòng thương của người khác
examples: ▪ She had lain in her bed for years, feigning illness and playing on the sympathy of her daughters.
▪ He decided it was best to play for sympathy on this occasion, because she might know if he tried to lie.

children.name: to tell sb that you sympathize with them
offer your sympathy
children.definition: /ˌɒfəʳ jɔːʳ ˈsɪmpəθiǁˌɔːf-/  formal to tell someone that you feel sympathy for them, especially in a letter, after someone they love has died:kính cẩn chia buồn
examples: ▪ She wrote a short letter offering her sympathy.
▪ Bouquets and hand-written cards offering sympathy surrounded the scene of the accident.
offer your sympathy to: kính cẩn chia buồn với ai
▪ My husband joins me in offering our sincere sympathy to you and to Susan at this sad time.

children.name: commiserate
children.definition: /kəˈmɪzəreɪt/  formal to express your sympathy for someone when they are unhappy about something, especially something that is not really very serious:động lòng thương xót
examples: ▪ ‘Poor Alistair!’ she commiserated. ‘Let me buy you lunch.’
commiserate with: động lòng thương xót với ai
▪ When he failed his driving test, I called him up and commiserated with him.
commiserate about: động lòng thương xót về chuyện gì
▪ In several of their letters, Hartley and Burns commiserated about the problems of old age.
commiseration/kəˌmɪzəˈreɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]sự động lòng, thương xót
▪ ‘I’m afraid I didn’t have any success,’ I said, and my colleague shook his head in commiseration.

children.name: send/offer/express condolences
children.definition: /ˌsend, ˌɒfəʳ, ɪkˌspres kənˈdəʊlənszǁ-ˌɔːf-/  to express sympathy to someone whose close relative or friend has died - use this in formal or official situations:gửi/bày tỏ sự thương xót, chia buồn
examples: send/offer/express condolences to gửi/bày tỏ sự thương xót, chia buồn đến ai
▪ We take this opportunity to send our condolences to the families of those who lost their lives in this disaster.
▪ After the funeral, foreign ambassadors lined up to offer their condolences to the widow of the late president.
deep/heartfelt/sincere condolences: lời chia buồn sâu sắc/từ tấm lòng/sâu sắc
▪ In a statement read on television, Saleh expressed ‘deepest condolences’ to the families of the victims.

children.name: what you say to tell sb that you sympathize
I’m sorry
children.definition: /aɪm ˈsɒriǁ-ˈsɑːri/ spoken say this to tell someone you are sad that something bad has happened to them:tôi rất tiếc
examples: ▪ I heard about your father’s death; I’m very sorry.
▪ Jules, I am sorry. I had no idea.I’m sorry about
▪ Mavis, I’m really sorry about your Ma. It must have been a terrible shock.

children.name: I/we’ll be thinking of you
children.definition: /aɪ, wiːl biː ˈθɪŋkɪŋ əv juː/ spoken say this to tell someone that you are worried about them and that you hope they will be all right:tôi sẽ nhớ cậu lắm
examples: ▪ Take care, Lucy. I’ll be thinking of you.
▪ Tell Harry I’ll be thinking of him and I hope he’ll be home soon.

children.name: bad luck
children.definition: /ˌbæd ˈlʌk/ British spoken say this to show your sympathy for someone who has tried to do something and failed:không may rồi! (thật xui xẻo)
examples: ▪ Bad luck, Paul. I’m sure you’ll pass next time.
▪ Oh what a shame. Bad luck Chris.

children.name: you have my deepest sympathy
children.definition: /with deepestsympathy /juː ˌhæv maɪ ˌdiːpst ˈsɪmpəθi, wɪð ˌdiːpst ˈsɪmpəθi/ formal written use this in a letter to someone you do not know very well, whose close relative or friend has died:thành thật chia buồn, lời chia buồn sâu sắc đến ai
examples: ▪ We were so sorry to hear of your sister’s death. You have our deepest sympathy.

children.name: sympathy
children.definition: /ˈsɪmpəθi/  the feeling you have when you are sorry for someone who is having problems, and you understand how they feel:cảm thông
examples: ▪ Relatives of the aircrash victims were treated with great sympathy.
▪ She looked at him with sympathy.
▪ The trip also is intended to raise money and sympathy for the plight of the Tibetan people.
have/feel/express sympathy for somebody: có/cảm thấy/bày tỏ sự cảm thông cho ai
▪ The Prime Minister expressed outrage at the attack, and sympathy for the families of the victims.
deep sympathya very strong feeling of sympathy:cảm thông sâu sắc
▪ You have my deepest sympathy, and my thoughts are with you.

children.name: pity
children.definition: /ˈpɪti/  a feeling that you have when you feel very sorry for someone, often when you are unable to help them:thương hại
examples: ▪ It’s a civil war. They don’t want our pity, they need our help.
▪ When I returned to school, my classmates looked at me with pity in their eyes.
feel/have pity: cảm thấy thương hại
▪ I felt such pity for that young girl sitting alone in the bus station.
be full of pity/be filled with pity: đầy sự thương hại
▪ She was full of pity for the little boy with no one to love and care for him.

children.name: understanding
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈstændɪŋ/  a sympathetic attitude to someone that is based on your understanding:sự thông hiểu, thông cảm
examples: ▪ Demonstrate your empathy and understanding of your children’s problems.
▪ There seems to be a lack of understanding on the part of managers when it comes to employees’ personal problems.
▪ The book gave me an understanding of what it must be like to be addicted to drugs.

children.name: compassion
children.definition: /kəmˈpæʃən/  a strong feeling of pity for someone who is suffering, and a desire to help them:lòng thương, lòng trắc ẩn
examples: ▪ Of course we must insist on punishment, but the criminal must also be treated with compassion.
compassion for/to/towards: lòng thương/lòng trắc ẩn cho ai/tới ai/ đối với ai/cái gì
▪ Russell’s father had no compassion for his son’s physical disabilities
.▪ What are you doing now to show compassion toward the victims of torture?

children.name: feel sorry because sb else is in a bad situation
feel sorry for
children.definition: to feel sad for sb because they have had bad luck or they are in a bad situation: cảm thương cho ai
examples: I think he felt sorry for me because I’d just lost my wallet.
He’ll probably go to jail for this. It’s his wife I feel sorry for.
I feel sorry for the poor person who’s going to have to sort this mess out.
I feel really sorry for young married couples these days. It’s hard going for them.
can’t help feeling sorry for sb[use this when you should not really feel sorry for sb, but you do]
I know he’s being a jerk, but I can’t help feeling a little sorry for him.

children.name: have sympathy for
children.definition: have/ feel sympathy for to feel sad for sb who is having problems, because you understand how they feel: có sự cảm thông cho ai
examples: I have great sympathy for anyone who has lived through depression.
It wasn’t possible not to feel sympathy for Anna -- she’d lost her husband and her son in the space of only a few weeks.
have/ feel deep sympathy for:
The judge said he had the deepest sympathy for Maria’s situation, but that he had no option but to sentence her.

children.name: pity
children.definition: to feel very sorry for sb who is in a much worse situation than you: thương hại
examples: I pity anyone who has to feed a family on such a low income.
I don’t want you to pity me - I just want you to help me.
He felt pity for Marla out there all by herself in some little nowhere town.

children.name: my heart goes out to
children.definition: sb  use this to say that you feel extremely sorry for sb, especially because sth very sad has happened to them: với sự thương cảm sâu sắc cho ai ; với tấm lòng thành kính dành cho...
examples: I know how awfully disappointed you must be, and my heart goes out to you.
My heart went out to all those poor little children standing shivering in the cold.

children.name: sympathize
children.definition: alsosympathise  to feel sad for sb who is having problems, because you understand how they feel: thông cảm
examples: My dear, I completely understand and sympathize, but there’s not much I can do about it, really.
sympathize with
She felt Mark should have sympathised with her and supported her, instead of criticizing.
sympathize with sb’s plight /problems /dilemma
It’s hard not to sympathize with the plight of single parents in today’s world.

children.name: understand
children.definition: /ˌʌndəʳˈstænd/  to realize that someone is unhappy or having problems, and behave kindly to them:cảm thông, thấu hiểu
examples: ▪ I’m sure if you talk to your boss, he’ll understand.
▪ You can only apologize, and hope that she’ll understand.
understand why/what/how: thấu hiểu tại sao/cái gì/như thế nào
▪ I completely understand how things are when money is tight.
▪ We’re trying very hard to understand what she’s going through.

children.name: feel for
children.definition: sb to sympathize very strongly and sincerely with sb who has problems, is suffering etc: cảm thương cho ai
examples: Of course I feel for him - he’s my brother. But he did bring it on himself.
You couldn’t help but feel for Charles. He’d been so unlucky in life.

children.name: identify with
children.definition: sb/sthto feel sympathy with someone or be able to share their feelings :đồng cảm với ai
examples: Humans can easily identify with the emotional expressions of chimpanzees.
He identified with our distress.
Many women of normal weight feel unable to identify with the super-thin models in glossy magazines.

children.name: sensitivity
children.definition: the ability to understand other people’s feelings and problems :
examples: His comments show a lack of sensitivity.
Interviewing victims of crime must be done with sensitivity.
a teacher withgreat sensitivity
sensitivity to
She has alwaysshownasensitivityto audience needs and tastes.

children.name: relate to
children.definition: sbphrasal verbto understand someone and be able to have a friendly relationship with them hiểu
examples: _Many parents find it hard to relate to their children when they are teenagers.
